interactivity: its hinged lid could be opened
hapticFeedback: When the user touches the chest’s lid, they should feel the fine grain and slight ridges of a weathered wooden surface (medium-rough friction, 50% emphasis). Reaching up to lift the lid, they encounter a hinged resistance—an initial stiff detent followed by a smooth pivot and a light metallic click at the end of travel (high interactivity). A good physical proxy is a small wooden box with a real hinge and latch: it provides the same grainy wood texture under the fingertips and realistic hinge torque and click.

Users grasp the round bow of the key and should sense a smooth, polished metal finish (40% emphasis) wrapping around their finger. The large ring-shaped outline (70% emphasis) must register as a circular, rigid loop. When pressed against a virtual lock, they feel the slight bevel of the bit edges. A good proxy is an actual brass or steel skeleton key with the same ring diameter and slender shank: it preserves the smoothness, ring shape, and tactile cues of the teeth.

As the user holds the pistol frame, attention turns to the pullable trigger (100% interactivity). They should experience a firm but not overly heavy trigger pull with a clear break at mid-stroke and a quick spring-back or reset click. The grip itself can be smooth plastic or metal but the key sensation is the crisp trigger response. A good proxy is a toy or training pistol that has a realistic metal trigger mechanism—providing the precise pull weight, travel distance, and audible/tactile reset.

description: a frisbee that players can throw
outline: holding part feels like a thin plate
hapticFeedback: On grabbing the Frisbee’s rim, users should perceive a thin rigid plate edge with negligible weight (70% inertia, 70% outline). The wrist feels the low inertia as they flick the disc: light, nearly effortless acceleration, and a floating slipperiness. A suitable proxy is a standard lightweight plastic Frisbee—thin-edged, low mass, and easily flicked for the same effortless toss sensation.

description: a steering wheel in a car
hapticFeedback: When the user’s hands wrap around the steering wheel rim, they should feel a smooth, slightly rubberized grip rotating under their palms. Turning it conveys steady torque with a slight damping or resistance that mimics steering mechanics (90% interactivity). A good proxy is an automotive or racing-game steering wheel controller with adjustable resistance, so users feel consistent rotary force and smooth uninterrupted rotation.

Upon contact, the tomato must feel soft and easily deformable (100% hardness emphasis). The surface yields under light finger pressure, giving a squishy, resilient resistance and then springing back partially. A fitting proxy is a soft foam or rubber stress-ball shaped like a tomato, providing realistic dimple-in and rebound when squeezed or smashed.

inertia: relatively heavy with the center of mass concentrated at one end
hapticFeedback: Grasping the round handle, users sense a cylindrical grip with a smooth finish. When swung, they should feel a pronounced heavy head (70% inertia) at the distal end—causing a strong torque pull on the wrist and a weighty, pendulum-like momentum. The handle’s round outline (40% outline) must fill the palm. A well-chosen proxy is a real hammer or mallet with a heavy metal head and wooden or plastic round handle: it replicates the off-center mass and heft needed for realistic swings.
